primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The transformation of humanity from 'repulsive' and 'insecure' actors into 'beautiful people' through the bestowal of divine glory by Jesus Christ.

tekstueel_bewijs: the Lord can grant us his beauty
the glory which thou gavest me I have given them
Christ gives to us his glory
He sets us down at his table

object.identificatie: Divine Glory / Beauty / Communion with God
tekstueel_bewijs: the divine character shedding its brilliant glow
the luminous, warm, bright blessedness of the divine person
the glory which thou gavest me
becomes ours by the gift of Jesus
we are beautiful in that spiritual privilege
His was a constant communion with God
The word of Jesus previously cited haunts us still
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject and the Source

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin, Death, and the Illusion of Self-Sufficiency
tekstueel_bewijs: Sin soils and sours our lives
death delivers the final, fatal blow
the illusion abroad that life can be made beautiful by the common sense of men
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not merely bad habits but ontological realities (Sin, Death) that humans cannot overcome alone.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human attempt to achieve beauty through wealth, power, or self-improvement (The 'Invictus' program).
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The 'Idle Rich' / Power Brokers / The Self-Reliant Man
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: This program is presented as a failed precursor or a false alternative that leads to 'repulsiveness' rather than beauty.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: God the Father → Divine Glory → The Believers

voorbeelden_god_subject: the Lord can grant us his beauty
He has made us princes and princesses
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we can all make ourselves better people
they are likely to be sniffing cocaine
we shall walk through the fire

voorbeelden: We ought to have particular times set apart
wish that we could scamper hither and yon
When will we learn to differ intensely
the Lord can grant us his beauty
We shall be able to turn back every enemy

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes human 'non-pouvoir' (inability) in contrast to the divine 'pouvoir' (power) granted as a gift.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From ~S1 (the false beauty of the rich) to S2 (the reality of sin/death), then through the compassion of Jesus to S1 (true beauty).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in the 'gift' (Transmission) from Christ to the believer, bypassing human effort.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; sin and death are described as 'final, fatal blows' that humans cannot escape.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon begins with social commentary, it pivots to a radical theocentricity where beauty is an ontological gift from Christ, not a moral achievement.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Stay close to him in sunshine and storm.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Christ gives to us his glory. He makes us joint heirs.
While we can all make ourselves better people, we cannot make ourselves beautiful people.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures (Jesus) are not presented as examples to mimic by effort, but as the source of the climate believers are 'taken into'.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: Jesus (as the source, not just example)

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'desperate, losing battle' of self-creation; assurance.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic sanctification (God is the one who makes the person beautiful).

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'ugly' reality of the world to the 'glory' of Christ is logically and narratively tight.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'we cannot make ourselves beautiful' and the later exhortation to 'commune with him all of the time'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus moved in a climate full of the presence of God... The beautiful people are those who have been led by Jesus to live in God.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The 'glory' acts as the endowment of competence (Pouvoir-faire).

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; described as a 'trap of the spirit' and 'repulsive'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God/Christ as the Subject of the primary narrative program. The hearer is positioned as the Receiver of a gift (Glory) rather than the Subject of a task.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The middle section on 'minority leaders' briefly shifts the hearer into a 'Judge' role.
identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: Maintain the 'Sheep without a shepherd' identification.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Ensure the social critique always resolves back into the shared human 'lack' that only the Subject (Christ) fills.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Slightly more Savoir (How to live in the glory).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Briefly expand on how the 'glory' practically manifests in the 'dull routine' mentioned.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: Strong (Sin, Death, and the Devil are implied/stated).

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (Christ gives glory) correctly precedes and enables Ethics (We walk in peace).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in theocentric preaching that uses social observation to highlight a deep ontological need only met by the divine Subject.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'Beautiful People' metaphor; Greimas shows that the metaphor's power comes from the Subject-switch from Man to Christ.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains John 17; semiotics explains how the 'Glory' functions as a modal competence (Pouvoir) for the hearer.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the sermon's 'engine' is the Axis of Transmission (Sender to Receiver), making it a pure Grace narrative.

appendices.notities: The sermon avoids the 'Exemplarism' trap by making Jesus' prayer life the 'climate' we are invited into, rather than a checklist to perform.
